Headline: New Century's Reduced Assets Highlight Effects Of 2005 Law
Story: By Patrick Fitzgerald     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     Changes in the U.S. Bankruptcy Code allowed New Century Financial Corp.'s (NEWC) lenders to seize assets they wouldn't have been able to previously, explaining why a company that listed assets of $25 billion last September had just $36 million six months later.   The legal changes give big Wall Street institutions -- so-called warehouse lenders that provide credit to subprime mortgage lenders like New Century -- an exemption from the law's automatic stay provision. The provision, a cornerstone of U.S. bankruptcy law, blocks creditors from immediately seizing property for payment of a debt.   In 2005, Congress amended the bankruptcy law to add mortgage loans and "interests in mortgage loans" to the definition of financial instruments that could be included in repurchase agreements. The expanded definition, in many cases, put subprime mortgage lending outside the purview of bankruptcy law.   The definition changes were driven by powerful Wall Street and government forces -- the Bond Market Association, and the President's Working Group on Financial Markets, said Richard Levin, a partner in Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom's restructuring department. The Working Group includes the U.S. Treasury Secretary, the Federal Reserve chairman and the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.   "The Bond Market Association probably had the largest role in lobbying for the changes," Levin said. "Secured creditors, not surprisingly, don't like their loans subject to bankruptcy and over time they've learned ways to exempt themselves. They use bankruptcy-remote vehicles and they also get Congress to make amendments."           Repos Get Special Exemption Under Bankruptcy Law   Subprime lenders like New Century depend on credit lines from investment banks. The credit lines are backed by mortgage loans and are characterized as repurchase agreements, or repos. The repos are afforded a special exemption under bankruptcy law and provide the banks a "safe harbor" from the automatic stay.   Levin and other bankruptcy professionals maintain the exemptions have done what they were intended to do: encourage lending to home buyers with shaky credit by giving creditors more protection.   But with the change to the bankruptcy laws, New Century's warehouse lenders -- Bank of America Corp. (BAC), Citigroup Inc. (C), Credit Suisse Group (CS), Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) -- were free to seize their collateral and, in some cases, sell it.   The result: New Century and other subprime lenders - ResMae Mortgage Corp., People's Choice Financial Corp., Mortgage Lenders Network USA Inc. - that have filed for bankruptcy in recent months are little more than shells by the time they reach Chapter 11.   New Century, the country's second-largest subprime lender, collapsed into bankruptcy proceedings April 2, saying it had more than $7 billion in "principal indebtedness" in the form of repos.   The company is selling its servicing business, which handles loan payments and processing, to Carrington Capital Management LLC, Greenwich, Conn., for $139 million, and a small number of loans and residual interest in some trusts to Greenwich Capital for $50 million, subject to bankruptcy court approval.    Hedge fund Citadel Investment Group LLC  picked up ResMae's assets for about $24 million after Credit Suisse balked at buying $160 million in new mortgage loans generated by ResMae after its bankruptcy filing. But in both cases, the billions of dollars in loans securing the credit lines were already gone.                     "There Is No Debtors' Lobby"   "What this really means is that in this area of the law there is no balance between the rights of secured creditors and the ability of a mortgage lender to reorganize, because the secured creditors get to stand up the minute a bankruptcy filing is made and take their marbles and go home," said Levin. "There is no debtors' lobby."   New Century, of course, also hasn't disclosed all of its assets. For example, it hasn't yet specified the assets of its operating subsidiary, New Century TRS Holdings Inc. That unit holds the servicing operations and loans and trusts that are going on the auction block next month. The unit on Thursday asked  a judge for more time to file a detailed accounting of its assets and liabilities.   With bankruptcy looming, New Century said last month that all of its warehouse lenders were pulling their funding. Under the repo agreements with its lenders, New Century was on the hook for $8.4 billion, an amount the company couldn't pay.   Officials at New Century declined to comment. But in an affidavit filed in the company's Chapter 11 case, New Century's assistant general counsel, Monika McCarthy, said some warehouse lenders had already seized their loans and were selling them on the secondary market.   Last week, just days before New Century filed for bankruptcy, Morgan Stanley announced it was selling about $2.5 billion in mortgages that it seized from the company. But amid severely depressed market conditions, experts said, the warehouse lender isn't likely to recover the full value of its investment.   "The problem is it's a pretty lousy market" in which to unload subprime mortgage loans, said David Neier, a partner at Winston & Strawn. "But the creditors are saying 'Rome is burning! The market is going down! I want to take my chips and go home.'"    -Patrick Fitzgerald, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-3544; patrick.fitzgerald@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 13:51 ET (17:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Alaska Air Expects To Report Net Loss For 1Q >ALK
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Alaska Air Group Inc. (ALK) said it expects to report a net loss for the first quarter of 2007.   Alaska's March mainline traffic increased 0.5% to 1.532 billion revenue passenger miles, capacity rose 2.3% to 1.994 billion available seat miles, and passenger load factor fell to 76.8% from 78.2% a year ago.   The airline carried 1,448,200 passengers in March compared with 1,456,800 in March 2006.   -Sarah Turner; 415-439-6400; AskNewswires@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 06:22 ET (10:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Datascope To Pay Former Fincl Chief $250,000 Severance >DSCP
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     Datascope Corp. (DSCP) disclosed Friday that it will pay former chief financial officer Scott Kantor a $250,000 severance, less deductions, over a period of one year from April 3.   The company said in a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it will continue to provide medical benefits for a period of one year from April 3 or until Kantor begins full-time employment, whichever is sooner.   As reported Wednesday, Kantor resigned to pursue other opportunities.   The Montvale, N.J., company named Hank Scaramelli, corporate vice president and controller, as acting chief financial officer.   Shares of Datascope closed Thursday at $36.78 each.   -Chad Clinton, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-1349; chad.clinton@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 10:13 ET (14:13 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: KKR Admonishes TXU For Threatening To Shut Power Plants -2-
Story: "We're extremely unhappy that (TXU) did not consult with us first," before filing its response with state regulators threatening plant shutdowns, said Jeff Eller, a spokesman with KKR. "This is not how the investors want to do business as the new TXU, and we will not do business that way if this transaction closes."   Meanwhile, TXU publicly apologized for threatening to shut down power plants.   "TXU apologizes for creating any perception of threatening to shut down power plants in Texas," said Michael McCall, chief executive of TXU Wholesale, in a statement Friday. "TXU is not permitted to unilaterally shut down power plants."   McCall said the company would request that the commission disregard its filing this week and would submit a "more appropriate document after consulting with the investors."   TXU Chief Executive John Wilder said the company would "start over, consult with the investor group and get it right the next time."   In its filing this week with the commission, TXU had said the $210 million penalty would make it difficult for the Dallas-based utility to profitably operate older natural gas-fired plants. The company had suggested that it would ask the power grid operators to shut down plants. The grid, run by ERCOT, could approve the request or take over operation of the plants, TXU had proposed. TXU claimed it needed to charge prices that cover the short-term cost of fuel plus the expense of maintaining seldom-used plants the rest of the year. In some states, generators are paid just for keeping peak capacity available, but in Texas the power grid, run by ERCOT, pays only for the fuel.   KKR and TGP publicly urged TXU to settle the charges with the PUCT.   "Today we are asking and strongly advising TXU to settle this issue with the Public Utility Commission and reach an agreement with the PUC in regard to future actions as they pertain to the balancing energy offers to ensure that affordable and reliable power will be available at all times," KKR and TGP said in their statement.   In addition to KKR and TGP, other investors in the TXU buyout include Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS), Citigroup Inc. (C) and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. (LEH).     -By Cassandra Sweet, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-4427; cassandra.sweet@dowjones.com   (The Associated Press contributed to this article)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 15:33 ET (19:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 3rd UPDATE: Japan Banks Preparing Credit Line For Citigroup
Story: (Adds background, closing share price.)     TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Mizuho Corporate Bank and other major Japanese banks are preparing to form a credit line of up to Y1.7 trillion for Citigroup Inc. (C) to help fund the U.S. financial giant's bid to buy Nikko Cordial Corp. (8603.TO).   In what would amount to the biggest syndicated loan in Japan ever, Mizuho, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. and Citigroup's Citibank N.A. "are preparing to provide" a Y1.4 trillion line of credit, with an option for an additional Y300 billion, a source close to the matter said Friday.   Such a loan would shatter the previous record of Y1.28 trillion that Softbank Corp. procured last year to buy the Japan operations of U.K. mobile phone operator Vodafone Group PLC.   Citigroup said Friday it planned to procure a yen-denominated loan to help fund its bid for Nikko, though it didn't provide the names of the lenders or elaborate on details such as the amount or the timeframe.   The news suggests Citigroup is determined to successfully complete its tender offer to buy Nikko Cordial despite criticism from some Nikko shareholders about Citigroup's offering price. In addition to the benefit of low Japanese interest rates, the yen-denominated loans may help Citigroup reduce its exposure to currency fluctuation risks.   The U.S. bank is aiming to buy at least a majority of Nikko Cordial in a Y1,700 per-share tender offer that runs through April 26.   Citigroup considers an acquisition of the Japanese brokerage an important way to expand its business in the world's second biggest economy. Charles Prince, the bank's chief executive, has said he wants to raise the percentage of Citigroup's overseas revenue to 60% from the current level of 44%. Acquiring Nikko Cordial would help it achieve that goal because Japan's stock market is the world's second largest after the U.S. and its government bond market is the world's biggest.   If completed, the transaction would be the largest purchase of a Japanese company by a foreign acquirer, according Dealogic Ltd., a data tracker.   Shinichi Ina, banking analyst at Credit Suisse Securities, said that financing from major Japanese banks would enable Citigroup to build a relationship with them, something that could be worth more than money.   "(Syndicated loans from Japanese banks) would help Citigroup operate its business more easily here in Japan," Ina said.   Spokesmen at Mizuho Corporate Bank, Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ  and Sumitomo Mitsui declined to comment.   Citigroup said in a statement that "this yen loan facility, which is for general corporate purpose, is part of Citigroup's global borrowings program and it will help us better match the currency requirements of the recently announced Nikko Cordial transaction."   News of the potential loan comes on the same day that another major Nikko Cordial shareholder expressed dissatisfaction with Citigroup's current offering price. Southeastern Asset Management Inc. said earlier Friday it placed an order to sell a 6.6% stake in the brokerage at Y1,900 per share.   "Southeastern has decided that it will accept Y1,900 per share... (and) has placed a limit order to sell 64,424,500 shares," a spokesman for the U.S. fund said.   A number of investors have been critical of the pricing of Citigroup's bid, which has already been revised higher from its initial Y1,350 per share offer after a surprise decision by the Tokyo Stock Exchange not to delist the brokerage for its accounting problems.   Bermuda-based investment fund Orbis Investment Management Ltd., which has also voiced dissatisfaction with Citigroup's asking price, placed a limit-sell order at Y1,900 for some 70 million Nikko Cordial shares earlier this week.   Some market players believe that if there are more sell orders above Citigroup's offer price, the U.S. bank may be forced into upping its offer once again.   Shares of Nikko ended up 0.9% at Y1,715 on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after rising as high as Y1,720.     -By Hiroyuki Kachi and Jamie Miyazaki, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; hiroyuki.kachi@dowjones.com, jamie.miyazaki@dowjones.com   (Atsuko Fukase contributed to this story.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 02:08 ET (06:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Cambrex Announces Declaration of Special Cash Dividend, Closing on New Credit Facility, and Discontinuance of Regular Dividend
Story: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 6 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Cambrex Corporation ("Cambrex" or the "Company") (NYSE: CBM) announced today that its Board of Directors approved a one-time payment of $14.00 per share to shareholders through a special cash dividend. This dividend, which will total approximately $400 million, will be financed by approximately $300 million of cash on hand, principally from the remaining net proceeds from the recently completed sale of Cambrex's Bioproducts and Biopharma businesses, and approximately $100 million of borrowings under a new five year, $200 million credit facility entered into today with a commercial bank group led by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.        (Logo:  http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20000613/CAMBREXLOGO )     James A. Mack, Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer commented: "In early 2006, we announced our plan to evaluate strategic alternatives to enhance shareholder value. I am very pleased to announce that as a result of this process, the Company will make this significant one-time distribution of $14.00 per share to our shareholders."     Mack continued, "In addition to the dividend, our shareholders will retain their ownership interests in Cambrex, a focused provider of pharmaceutical products and services to both branded and generic pharmaceutical companies worldwide. Given our strong market position, experienced management team, sharp strategic focus, current momentum and positive market conditions, we are excited about our shareholders' ability to also participate in the Company's future performance and growth."     The special dividend is payable on May 3, 2007 to shareholders of record as of April 20, 2007. The dividend is subject to satisfaction of customary conditions to the drawdown of funds under the new credit facility on the dividend payment date.  Because of the magnitude of the special dividend, the New York Stock Exchange has determined that the ex-dividend date will be May 4, 2007, the business day following the payment date.  Shareholders of record on the April 20, 2007 record date who subsequently sell their shares of common stock prior to or on the payment date of May 3, 2007 will also be selling their right to receive the special cash dividend. Accordingly, shareholders are advised to contact their financial advisors before selling their shares.     For U.S. federal income tax purposes, the distribution will be a dividend to the extent it is paid out of the Company's current or accumulated earnings and profits, as determined under U.S. federal income tax principles.  Based on these rules, the Company currently estimates that 55%-65% of the payment will be treated as a dividend for tax purposes, with the balance being a return of capital. This estimate is preliminary and subject to change based upon a comprehensive review and analysis of the Company's history as well as actual results for the entire 2007 taxable year.  Shareholders will receive a Form 1099-DIV in early 2008 notifying them of the portion of the special cash dividend that is treated as a dividend for U.S. federal income tax purposes. Shareholders are encouraged to consult with their own tax and financial advisors regarding the implications of this special distribution.     The Company also announced that, effective immediately, the Board of Directors is discontinuing its quarterly dividend payment and will instead allocate these cash outlays to support its growth initiatives.        Forward Looking Statements     This news release may contain "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and Rule 3b-6 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, including, without limitation, statements regarding expected performance, especially expectations with respect to sales, research and development expenditures, earnings per share, capital expenditures, acquisitions, divestitures, collaborations, or other expansion opportunities.  These statements may be identified by the fact that words such as "expects", "anticipates", "intends", "estimates", "believes" or similar expressions are used in connection with any discussion of future financial and/or operating performance.  Any forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the risk factors discussed in the Company's periodic reports filed with the SEC.  Any forward- looking statements contained herein are based on current plans and expectations and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual outcomes and results to differ materially from current expectations including, but not limited to, global economic trends, pharmaceutical outsourcing trends, competitive pricing or product developments, government legislation and/or regulations (particularly environmental issues), tax rate, interest rate, technology, manufacturing and legal issues, including the outcome of outstanding litigation disclosed in the Company's public filings, changes in foreign exchange rates, performance of minority investments, uncollectible receivables, loss on disposition of assets, cancellation or delays in renewal of contracts, lack of suitable raw materials or packaging materials, the Company's ability to receive regulatory approvals for its products, the outcome of the evaluation of strategic alternatives, the availability of financing for the special dividend under the Company's new credit facility and the accuracy of the Company's current estimate set forth in this release with respect to its earnings and profits for tax purposes in 2007.  Any forward- looking statement speaks only as of the date on which it is made, and the Company undertakes no obligation to publicly update any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. New factors emerge from time to time and it is not possible for us to predict which new factors will arise.  In addition, we cannot assess the impact of each factor on the Company's business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements.     For further details and a discussion of these and other risks and uncertainties, investors and security holders are cautioned to review the definitive proxy statement filed January 4, 2007 in respect of the Special Meeting of Shareholders dated February 5, 2007, the Cambrex 2006 Annual Report on Form 10-K, including the Forward-Looking Statement section therein, and other subsequent filings with the SEC, including Current Reports on Form 8-K.        About Cambrex     Cambrex provides products and services to accelerate the development and commercialization of branded and generic small molecule therapeutics. The Company currently employs approximately 850 worldwide. For more information, please visit http://www.cambrex.com.    SOURCE  Cambrex Corporation       /CONTACT: Robert Thomson, Director, Investor Relations of Cambrex Corporation, +1-201-804-3047, bob.thomson@cambrex.com      /Web site: http://www.cambrex.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 11:17 ET (15:17 GMT)

Headline: Long Enamoured With Gasoline, US Refiners Court Diesel Market
Story: (This article was originally published Thursday.)     By Beth Heinsohn     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Rising global demand for diesel is reshaping the U.S. oil refining industry.   While most U.S. motorists pay scant attention to the high price of the trucking fuel when filling up their cars with gasoline, refiners have taken note and are moving to boost capacity for the production of diesel. With long-distance freight hauling increasing steadily in the U.S. - and diesel consumption in Europe and Asia growing even faster - fuel producers are looking to diesel for profit growth as the race to supply the U.S. gasoline market gets more competitive.   "There's a hydrocracker trend," said Horace Hobbs, a Houston-based industry consultant with Muse Stancil, referring to processing units vital to the production of very-low sulfur diesel fuel mandated for use since late 2006. "If you have high diesel prices, that'll drive you to hydrocrackers."   Energy companies are gauging changes in fuel markets and making plans for billions of dollars of refinery modifications. Having already invested billions into upgrades that were mandated by clean-air regulations, refiners - still flush with cash from high profits - face tough decisions on how to alter their production facilities.   Refiners can't build their way to greater profits just by enlarging plants to process more crude oil.   "People think there's a global refining capacity shortage, but there isn't," said Mike Wilcox, head of downstream oil consulting for Edinburgh, Scotland-based Wood Mackenzie. "There's regional tightness, but that's not the same thing."   U.S. refiners are under pressure from equity markets to boost near-term profits with every plant modification while contending with rising cost inflation, lengthening project timelines and the ultimate moving target - supply and demand.            Capitalizing On Diesel Demand Growth     Outright gasoline demand in the U.S. is triple that of diesel but the rate at which diesel demand is growing is double that of gasoline. Good economic times have meant that heavy-duty trucks are logging more and more miles to keep up with the rising demand for goods.   The profits refiners can realize from processing a barrel of crude oil into transportation and heating fuels already reflect that greater diesel demand, according to the largest independent refiner in North America.   In a presentation to analysts this week, Valero Energy Corp. (VLO) President Greg King touted the strong outlook for diesel, saying that, so far in 2007, the profit margin in processing the fuel on the Gulf Coast is $15 to $22 a barrel, 23% higher than a year ago and more than double the five-year average for the first quarter.   Burgeoning diesel demand growth is the guiding principle behind the expansion and upgrade of Marathon Oil Corp.'s (MRO) refinery in Garyville, La., company president Gary Heminger said.   Output at the 31-year-old plant, the last new refinery built in the U.S., will be evenly split between diesel and gasoline after plant capacity almost doubles to 425,000 barrels a day by the end of 2009. The standard configuration for complex refineries calls for gasoline and gasoline components to account for two-thirds of output, with diesel and other fuels making up the balance.   Major expansions and upgrades for two other Gulf Coast refineries also feature increased diesel production capacity. Motiva Enterprises LLC's project for its Port Arthur, Texas, refinery, includes a hydrocracker as does the plan for Valero's St. Charles refinery in Norco, La.   The Motiva plan, partially underway but pending final approval, would more than double the Port Arthur refinery's capacity to 610,000 barrels a day. Valero is seeking permits to expand its St. Charles plant to 380,000 barrels a day, which would make the refinery the largest in the company's 17-plant system.   The pairing of increased diesel production with the transformation of the two plants into mega-refineries is no coincidence.   "We believe the global demand for diesel is going to grow more rapidly than gasoline and this expansion would capitalize on that trend," Rich Marcogliese, Valero's head of refining operations, told analysts in a conference call in late 2006.            Sticking Close To Home     Outside the U.S., diesel use has grown even more - by 5.5% on year in Western Europe and by 9.6% in Korea as of January, according to the International Energy Agency.   But foreign competitors to U.S. refiners are better placed to meet that galloping demand growth. New refineries, some massive, springing up in Asia and the Middle East, are closer to the fastest-growing markets - and biggest oilfields - than any in the U.S.   And the diesel produced in the U.S. takes longer to ignite, rendering it useless for European diesel engines and, thus, incompatible with the export market closest to the U.S.   "I don't see the U.S. as an exporter of diesel," said Muse Stancil's Hobbs. Economies of scale and proximity to growth markets favor gigantic refineries planned for Saudi Arabia, South Korea and India.It's likely that these plants will be able to undercut U.S. refiners on prices in the global market.   Basing refining close to the crude supply and diesel demand "is more efficient than first hauling the crude to where the refinery is and then moving the product to where the demand is," Hobbs said.     -By Beth Heinsohn, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-4435; beth.heinsohn@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 08:47 ET (12:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Service Corporation International Announces Early Participation Results and Pricing of Cash Tender Offers
Story: HOUSTON, April 6 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Service Corporation International (NYSE: SCI), a provider of deathcare products and services, announced today that the early participation period for its cash tender offers to purchase any and all of its 6.50% Notes due 2008 and 7.70% Notes due 2009 ended yesterday at 5:00 p.m., New York City time. At the end of the early participation period, SCI had received tenders from holders of approximately $149.1 million aggregate principal amount of its 6.50% Notes (of a total outstanding principal amount of $195.0 million) and approximately $173.8 million aggregate principal amount of its 7.70% Notes (of a total outstanding principal amount of $202.6 million).     The total consideration for each $1,000 principal amount of 6.50% Notes validly tendered prior to the early participation deadline is $1,009.17, which includes a $30.00 early participation payment but excludes accrued interest. The total consideration for each $1,000 principal amount of 7.70% Notes validly tendered prior to the early participation deadline is $1,048.30, which includes a $30.00 early participation payment but excludes accrued interest. Subject to the satisfaction or waiver of the conditions to each tender offer, holders of notes that have validly tendered prior to the early participation deadline will receive payment on the early payment date, which is expected to be April 9, 2007.     The total consideration for the 6.50% Notes was determined by reference to a fixed spread of 50 basis points over the bid-side yield of the 4.625% U.S. Treasury Note due February 29, 2008, which was calculated at 2:00 p.m.     New York City time, on April 5, 2007. The reference yield and the tender offer yield for the 6.50% Notes are 4.973% and 5.473%, respectively. The total consideration for the 7.70% Notes was determined by reference to a fixed spread of 50 basis points over the bid-side yield of the 3.125% U.S. Treasury Note due April 15, 2009, which was calculated at 2:00 p.m.     New York City time, on April 5, 2007. The reference yield and the tender offer yield for the 7.70% Notes are 4.647% and 5.147%, respectively.     Holders who tender 6.50% Notes after the early participation deadline, but prior to the expiration time, will receive the tender offer consideration of $979.17 per $1,000 principal amount of 6.50% Notes tendered and will not receive the early participation payment. Holders who tender 7.70% Notes after the early participation deadline, but prior to the expiration time, will receive the tender offer consideration of $1,018.30 per $1,000 principal amount of 7.70% Notes tendered and will not receive the early participation payment. Holders of notes that have been validly tendered following the early participation deadline, but prior to the expiration time, will receive payment on the final payment date, which is expected to be promptly after the expiration time.     The Company will pay applicable accrued and unpaid interest on the notes from the most recent payment of semi-annual interest preceding the payment date for the notes up to, but not including, such payment date.     The tender offers will expire at 12:00 midnight, New York City time, on Friday, April 20, 2007, unless terminated or extended. Each tender offer is     subject to a financing condition and certain general conditions, each as described in more detail in the Offer to Purchase.     Questions concerning the terms of the tender offers may be directed to the dealer managers, Banc of America Securities LLC at (888) 292-0070 (U.S. Toll- Free) or (704) 388-4813 (Collect) or Merrill Lynch & Co. at (888) 654-8637 (U.S. Toll-Free) or (212) 449-4914 (Collect). Copies of the Offer to Purchase may be obtained by calling the information agent, Global Bondholder Services Corporation, toll-free at (866) 387-1500 or at (212) 430-3774 (banks and brokerage firms).        CAUTIONARY STATEMENT ON FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS     The statements in this press release that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements made in reliance on the "safe harbor" protections provided under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements may be accompanied by words such as "believe," "estimate," project," "expect," "anticipate," or "predict," that convey the uncertainty of future events or outcomes. These statements are based on assumptions that we believe are reasonable; however, many important factors could cause our actual results in the future to differ materially from the forward-looking statements made herein and in any other documents or oral presentations made by, or on our behalf. Important factors which could cause actual results to differ materially from those in forward-looking statements include, among others, unfavorable market conditions, and our ability to successfully complete the tender offers.     For further information on these and other risks and uncertainties, see our Securities and Exchange Commission filings, including our 2006 Annual Report on Form 10-K. Copies of this document as well as other SEC filings can be obtained from our website at http://www.sci-corp.com. We assume no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements made herein or any other forward-looking statements made by us.     Service Corporation International (NYSE: SCI), headquartered in Houston, Texas, is North America's leading provider of deathcare products and services. At December 31, 2006 we owned and operated more than 1,600 funeral homes and 400 cemeteries (of which over 230 are combination locations) in 45 states, eight Canadian provinces, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Through our businesses, we market the Dignity Memorial(R) brand which offers assurance of quality, value, caring service, and exceptional customer satisfaction. For more information about Service Corporation International, please visit our website at http://www.sci-corp.com . For more information about Dignity Memorial(R), please visit http://dignitymemorial.com.          For additional information contact:        Investors:  Debbie Young - Director / Investor Relations      (713) 525-9088        Media:  Greg Bolton - Director / Corporate Communications      (713) 525-5235      SOURCE  Service Corporation International       /CONTACT: Investors, Debbie Young, Director, Investor Relations, +1-713-525-9088, Media, Greg Bolton, Director, Corporate Communications, +1-713-525-5235, both of Service Corporation International      /Web site: http://www.sci-corp.com      /Web site: http://dignitymemorial.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 08:24 ET (12:24 GMT)

Headline: Russia's MTS To Buy $100M Of Equipment From Ericsson -Report
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russia's No. 1 cellular operator by subscribers, OAO Mobile TeleSystems (MBT), has agreed to buy $100 million worth of telecoms equipment from Sweden's L.M. Ericsson Telephone Co. (ERIC), news agency Prime-Tass reported late Thursday, citing MTS.   The companies signed a framework agreement under which Ericsson will this year supply MTS with switchboards, radio access and GPRS, or General Packet Radio Service equipment, as well as multimedia solutions, MTS said.   MTS' other equipment suppliers include Motorola Inc. (MOT), Germany's Siemens A.G. (SI) and China's Huawei.   Agency Web site: http://www.prime-tass.com   -By Moscow Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 8055     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 01:50 ET (05:50 GMT)

Headline: PRACTICE MANAGEMENT: Financial Advice In The Time Of War
Story: By Kristen McNamara     A Dow Jones Newswires Column     (This article was originally published Thursday)     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Tim Wesling is drawing on his experience as a financial advisor and retired Air Force lieutenant colonel to help the families of service members killed on active duty.   Wesling, president of Wesling Financial Planning Services Corp. in Alexandria, Va., is part of a network of advisors tapped by a Chicago company to provide one-on-one financial counseling to beneficiaries of life and injury protection insurance offered by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.   The company, which is called ComPsych Corp. but does business with the military as FinancialPoint, referred one widow to Wesling late last year and a second one early this year.   Both women were accustomed to their husbands managing their money and the military handling many other aspects of their lives. Wesling is helping them with budgets, cash flow and estate plans and estimates it will take several months to get their finances in order and get them comfortable handling matters on their own.   "I do believe the kind of work that needs to be done with these particular clients is a little less number crunching and much more helping them through the transition," says Wesling, a fee-only planner who's been an advisor for the past 12 years following a two-decade career in the military.   FinancialPoint pays the hourly fee it negotiated with Wesling, which he says is lower than his usual fee.       Need, But Not Demand     Many financial advisors are keen to help the military in this time of war, but service members and their families don't seem to be clamoring for advice.   Just 54 beneficiaries received face-to-face counseling through FinancialPoint in 2006, according to Charles Strang, director of Prudential Financial Inc.'s (PRU) Office of Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance, which administers the insurance programs offered by the Veterans Affairs Department. Prudential contracted with FinancialPoint to provide financial advice to beneficiaries.   FinancialPoint counselors can answer questions by phone and develop financial plans from questionnaires beneficiaries complete and return. They can also refer individuals to the external certified financial planners they've vetted.   Prudential is working with the Veterans Affairs Department to develop a survey for eligible beneficiaries to determine why they have or haven't taken advantage of the free financial assistance available to them.   The supply of financial advisors interested in doing pro bono work for service members also seems to outnumber the available opportunities.   "There's need out there, but there's not necessarily demand," says Jonathan Sprague, director of pro bono services at the Financial Planning Association, which represents about 28,500 advisors and other financial professionals. "The people who need it don't necessarily understand what we can do."   A 2005 report from the NASD Investor Education Foundation illustrated the need for financial education among service members.   Almost a quarter of the nearly 1,600 active military personnel and spouses who participated in an online survey said they occasionally or usually have difficulty paying bills. And nearly a third said they'd had a negative investment experience that could have been avoided with greater knowledge.   The Defense Department launched a campaign in 2003 to educate service members and their families about personal finance in an effort to help them manage their money and protect themselves from predatory practices. The department partnered with federal agencies and nonprofit organizations to support employees at military installations who are responsible for providing education and counseling.   The FPA is working to become one of those official partners. In the meantime, Sprague is encouraging regional association chapters to form alliances with organizations that already work with the military.       FPA Pro Bono     The FPA has a memorandum of understanding with Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Volunteers from the association's Washington chapter have presented educational sessions to injured service members and their families and have provided advice in one-on-one sessions following the presentations.   The presentations address the steps in the financial planning process, including the need to determine goals and devise a plan.   The FPA's San Diego chapter recently partnered with a nonprofit group called Operation Homefront, which offers emergency and educational services and morale-boosting programs to military families.   The San Diego chapter volunteers will hold their first one-on-one advising session for military families April 17. They'll also provide group education seminars if there's interest, says Jon Beyrer, public relations director for the chapter and a certified financial planner at Blankinship & Foster LLC.   Participating advisors must attend two 1.5-hour training sessions to learn about the benefits, compensation and programs for military personnel, Beyrer says. The advisors also receive reference manuals.   The FPA has pro bono guidelines for advisors, which essentially require them to be certified financial planners or work under the supervision of a CFP, prohibit them from marketing their services or selling products to pro bono clients, and oblige them to provide the same level of service they'd provide a paying customer.   ComPsych also provides legal, financial, psychological and other services to 10,000 companies and government agencies around the world. Part of that work includes advising military reservists employed bythose organizations.   Budgeting is a big issue for reservists who are called to active duty, in part because their employers aren't required to make up the difference if their active duty pay is lower than their salaries. And business owners who are called up must worry about keeping the business going.   The NASD Investor Education Foundation has a number of resources for the military, including educational forums at military installations and an interactive Web site with information on saving and investing and service members' rights and responsibilities.   Its military education program was initially funded with the bulk of fines levied against a Texas financial services firm called First Command Financial Planning Inc. NASD and the Securities and Exchange Commission fined the company $12 million in 2004 for misleading practices related to the sale of investment plans to military personnel.     (Kristen McNamara writes about business issues facing financial advisors.)     -By Kristen McNamara, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5392; kristen.mcnamara@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 07:30 ET (11:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 3rd UPDATE: Judge Tells Vonage It Can't Seek New Customers
Story: (Adds comment from Verizon in the last two paragraphs.)       By Roger Cheng and Corey Boles     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--A U.S. federal judge ruled that Vonage Holdings Corp. (VG) will not be able to seek new customers, calling into question its ability to survive in the long run.   It's a damaging result for Vonage. U.S. District Court Judge Claude Hilton imposed an immediate stay against Vonage, effectively preventing it from signing up new customers to its Internet-based telephone service. The company, however, will be able to provide service to its existing base of 2.2 million customers.   Hilton said he had weighed a number of factors in reaching his decision. These, he said, included whether a stay could in fact lead to Vonage's bankruptcy. He also said he had to evaluate how the public's interest would be affected and concluded that given the competitiveness of the telecommunications industry, there would be no impact either way.   According to Rebecca Arboghast, a telecommunications analyst with Stifel Nicolaus who was at the hearing, if the ruling is upheld, it will be difficult for Vonage to "continue in a viable way."   Vonage's request for a stay of the injunction represented a near-last resort for the company, since a negative ruling would effectively shut down its Internet telephone business. The company is working on a way of developing a system that doesn't use Verizon patents, but it's unclear how much progress it has made in that avenue.   The Holmdel, N.J., Web phone service provider will appeal the original ruling that it had infringed on Verizon's patents, but the process could take more than a year. The quicker alternatives - a settlement or technology workaround - will take time and focus away from its core operation.   Still, the ruling is slightly better than the worst-case scenario of Vonage being forced to shut down its entire service. "It seems like a relatively fair compromise under the law," said Mark Kesslen, a partner at law firm Lowenstein Sandler PC that focuses on intellectual property. "But it hurts Vonage tremendously in a period where it's all about new client acquisition."   Verizon filed a brief Thursday pushing for the judge to deny Vonage's request. "A stay of injunction would violate the fundamental purpose of a stay pending appeal: preservation of the status quo."   Hilton concluded Friday's proceedings by saying he would enter the injunction order this coming Thursday, which in effect means that the injunction would begin at that date.   Vonage was dealt a serious blow March 23 when Hilton said he would issue a permanent injunction against Vonage. Shares plunged 26% that day. The only saving grace at the time was the judge's decision to wait two weeks before entering the injunction, allowing for more time to decide on the stay request.   The decision came after a jury found Vonage had infringed on three patents controlled by Verizon. The patents relate to connecting Internet phone calls with the traditional phone network, call forwarding and the use of wireless fidelity, or wi-fi, technology. Verizon claimed it lost hundreds of thousands of customers to Vonage while it used Verizon's patents.   Under the original jury ruling, Vonage would have to pay $58 million in damages and pay a 5.5% royalty rate for the technology. Verizon had sought $197 million.   "Verizon built a patent portfolio and is using it in an aggressive way to maintain and control its market share," Kesslen said.       A Bad Start     Vonage stumbled out of the gates with its initial public offering in May and has been hit with a myriad of problems. The company made a name for itself as the largest independent provider of Internet phone service, positioning itself as a low-cost alternative to the traditional phone companies. It, however, faces increasing competition from the cable providers, who have bundled their television service with a similar Web-based phone offering. The concern was partially the reason Vonage had to delay its IPO.   When Vonage did go public, it botched its IPO after offering shares to its customers, many of whom balked at paying for the stock they agreed to purchase. The company has been plagued by shareholder lawsuits and is still seeking compensation from its customers over the issue.   Those shareholders who stuck around saw nothing but grief from Vonage. After pricing at $17, the stock has continually hit all-time lows amid a barrage of negative news. Shares closed at $3.37 on Thursday.   In its most recently reported quarter, Vonage posted the weakest subscriber growth figure in two years. The company has eaten into some of the phone companies' subscriber base, but its impact is still minor. In 2006, Verizon lost 3.1 million residential phone customers, ending the year with a base of 27.8 million subscribers.   As a result of the anticipation over the decision, Vonage delayed filing its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission due to the uncertainty of the outcome at the time.   A spokesman for Vonage wasn't immediately available for comment.   In a statement, Verizon said it expects Hilton's ruling to be upheld on appeal.   "Judge Hilton exercised the court's equitable discretion to craft a middle path that allows Vonage to continue serving its existing customers while protecting Verizon's patents from increased infringement during the appeal process," said John Thorne, deputy general counsel at Verizon.   -By Roger Cheng, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-2020; roger.cheng@dowjones.com   -By Corey Boles, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-6637; corey.boles@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 15:53 ET (19:53 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Advanced Marketing Seeks Until Aug 10 To File Ch 11 Plan
Story: By Peg Brickley     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     WILMINGTON, Del. (Dow Jones)--Bankrupt book seller Advanced Marketing Services Inc. (MKTSQ) is asking a court to push off until August 10 the deadline by which it must file a Chapter 11 plan.   The company's time runs out April 28 if it doesn't win an extension of the so-called exclusive Chapter 11 plan filing period.   The California company filed for bankruptcy in Delaware Dec. 29, 2006, holding out hope it could reorganize and emerge from Chapter 11 as a standalone company.   Secured creditor Wells Fargo Foothill Inc., however, refused to fund a long-running bankruptcy, and worried publishers quit supplying the business.   By March, Advanced Marketing had sold its wholesale operation, which shuttled books to membership warehouse clubs such as BJ's Wholesale Club Inc, and its distribution business, Publishers Group West, which helped small independent publishers get their books to retail shelves.   Perseus Books LLC bought the Publishers Group West business, on terms that allowed it to pay off some of what the Advanced Marketing affiliate owed to independent publishers.   Baker & Taylor LLC has agreed to buy the wholesaling operations in a deal valued at more than $60 million.   In court papers filed Thursday, lawyers for Advanced Marketing say there's still work to be done before a Chapter 11 plan that sets out how cash raised in the sale of the businesses will be distributed.   Remaining operations are being wound down, and publishers are reclaiming unsold books. Both processes will affect the amount of debt that Advanced Marketing will have to tackle in its Chapter 11 plan, court documents say.   Bankruptcy law gives companies a limited amount of time to propose a Chapter 11 plan to pay creditors without competition from rival plans.   -By Peg Brickley, Dow Jones Newswires; 302-521-2266; peg.brickley@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 13:27 ET (17:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Bouygues Bought Alstom Shares For EUR6.81 Mln Last Week
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--French building-to-broadcasting conglomerate Bouygues SA (12050.FR) spent a total of EUR6.81 million last week on buying more shares in heavy engineering company Alstom SA (1022047.FR), according to filings with French financial markets regulator AMF.   Filings with the AMF stated that someone linked to Alstom board members Olivier Bouygues and Olivier Poupart-Lafarge bought the shares for between EUR93.966 and EUR94.384 each on March 26, 27 and 28.   A Bouygues spokeswoman confirmed Friday that the purchases had been made by Bouygues.   During the week before that, Bouygues bought EUR19.29 million-worth of Alstom shares. And between March 14 and March 16, Bouygues bought EUR16.61 million-worth of Alstom shares.   The spokeswoman was unable to provide a figure for Bouygues' current shareholding in Alstom.   Bouygues owned a 25.1% stake at the end of last year, and has stated that it doesn't intend to take control of Alstom, but that it may add to its shareholding in order to take advantage of market opportunities.   Alstom shares in Paris closed Thursday up EUR1.00, or 1%, at EUR100.75, in an overall flat market.   -By Alice Dore, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 4017 1740, alice.dore@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 08:56 ET (12:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =SMARTMONEY.COM/One-Day Wonder: Between RACK And A Hard Place
Story: By Will Swarts     Of SMARTMONEY.COM     (This article was originally published Thursday)    The Company  Rackable Systems (RACK)  Share price as of Wednesday's close: $16.88  Share price now: $14.25  Percent change: -15.5%  Volume: 18.3 million shares, daily average 2.4 million    The News   Investors in Rackable Systems found themselves behind the eight ball Thursday after the Milpitas, Calif., maker of servers and data systems warned that it would report a first-quarter loss. Shares banked and spun, closing down 15% going into the holiday weekend.   Rackable, whose equipment powers the giant server farms needed to run online properties like Amazon.com (AMZN) and Yahoo (YHOO), said increased competition from Dell (DELL) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) cut into its gross margins, slashing projections 30%. The company said it still expects quarterly revenue between $70 million and $75 million, but backed off earlier guidance on its margins, crushing Wall Street consensus projections of first-quarter earnings of a nickel a share.   The company didn't provide specific earnings guidance, but said it now expected gross margins of 12.5% to 14%, down from previous guidance of 18% to 20%. By that measure, Canaccord Adams' Mark Kelleher estimated a loss of four cents a share for the quarter; Troy Jensen of Piper Jaffray dropped his quarterly estimate to a loss of three cents. Rackable, which is scheduled to release earnings on April 26, earned 23 cents a share in the year-ago quarter.   "Intense competitive conditions for business at our largest customers continued throughout the first quarter of 2007, which negatively impacted our gross margin and bottom line," Chief Executive Tom Barton told analysts and investors on a Thursday morning conference call.   The bad news is a continuation of Rackable's woes from the fourth quarter of 2006, when Dell, storming in with much lower prices, effectively snatched away the smaller company's competitive advantage, prompting a massive year-to-year drop in earnings.   Rackable reported earnings of four cents a share in the last three months of 2006, down from 33 cents a share in the same period in 2005. Shares plummeted nearly 40% in a single session after it issued preliminary guidance on Jan. 16.   CEO Barton said the company also took a charge from the cancellation of one customer, but said "we believe that our position and our value proposition with our customers remains very strong."   The company plans to expand its customer base and enter into longer-term partnership arrangements with its largest customers. "We are very focused on stabilizing gross margins on these accounts," he said.    The Analysis   Rackable had a great run as an upstart, slipping into the server market a couple of years ago with superior processors from Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and stealing a march on H-P and Dell, which were using less efficient Intel (INTC) processors. About six months ago, management at Dell, Rackable's largest rival, fought back.   The results were clear last quarter, and the impact hasn't abated, says Canaccord's Kelleher.   "It was very clear that Dell was going to continue to press them on price," he said. In a note published Thursday, he observed that gross margins had sunk to the lowest level in the company's history, and wrote that "we believe management has been extremely clear as to its dire competitive position."   Piper Jaffray's Jensen said Rackable's order backlog for the first half of the year looks solid and is an encouraging sign, but added intense pricing competition means margins will keep ebbing throughout 2007.   It's a tough spot, according to Kelleher. While Rackable contends that Dell is selling its equipment at a loss to take away market share, its remedy of diversifying its customer base may not afford real relief. Rackable's top three customers are responsible for about 60% of its revenue, CEO Barton said.   "They talk about Dell coming after them in their key accounts, so they say they have a lot of hope they can get other key accounts," Kelleher says. "But I don't think Dell is going to be happy with just those accounts -- I think they'll go after all their accounts. And HP is also there. They're in a very competitive market without a lot of proprietary differentiation." In his note, Kelleher reiterated his Sell rating on the stock and added, "we continue to believe that Rackable's business model is flawed."   In pool, a player without a clear shot can look for an unseen angle, hope superior skill and fortuitous spin gets the ball to a pocket, or work at blocking his opponent with a tough leave. All these strategies may exceed Rackable's capacities as a small player up against giants.   Competitive pressures are compounded by inventory problems Rackable incurred in the December quarter, when it stocked up on dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, components just before a major price collapse. Since DRAM accounts for 20% to 30% of the cost of a Rackable server, the company hasn't helped its cause, says Kelleher. It will either have to sell through its pricey purchase, which will take very effective negotiations with its existing customers, who are already being wooed with lower prices by Dell, or take an inventory charge.   "Most of what could go wrong went wrong last quarter," he says, but that doesn't mean the problems have gone away.    The Bottom Line   Sometimes Goliath wins, even if there's sympathy for a plucky underdog. Dell is bigger, broader and richer than Rackable, and it's not going away. Rackable has a market cap of about $409 million. Dell's is $52 billion, and Hewlett-Packard's $111 billion, leaving them plenty of room to outspend the upstart rival.   "Let's say I'm pessimistic on future prospects," Kelleher says. "I don't see how they get out of it. I don't think it's a management issue -- they played the cards they were dealt as best they could, and they've been very forthright. If you ask what should they have done differently, I don't know."   The rapid drop in gross margin estimates pushed Jensen to drop his 2007 earnings estimate to 43 cents a share from a previous 90 cents. His 2008 projection dropped to 85 cents a share from $1.17.   While plans to expand its data-storage business sound plausible, Kelleher says there's about 1,600 pounds' worth of gorilla in that market as well, since Network Appliance (NTAP) and EMC (EMC) already have dominant positions.   If the company can take the market's punishment for a couple of quarters and plow proceeds into research and development, it may yet find a way to outmaneuver its deep-pocketed competition, but it'll be a tough task.   "Gross margins are going to be about 13% this quarter," Kelleher says. "At that level, you don't have enough money to invest in R&D to develop a proprietary defense against Dell."   Investors still hanging on to the stock should probably rack up their shares and find a better tech game.   -For more information and analysis of companies and mutual funds, visit SmartMoney.com at http://www.smartmoney.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 07:31 ET (11:31 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Schlumberger Responds to "Mini-Tender" Offer by TRC Corporation
Story: HOUSTON, April 6 /CNW/ - Schlumberger Limited (NYSE:SLB) announced today that it has been notified of an unsolicited "mini- tender" offer by TRC Capital Corporation to purchase up to 1,500,000 shares of Schlumberger common stock, representing approximately 0.13 percent of Schlumberger outstanding shares. TRC Capital's offer price of $67.75 represents, as TRC's own offer document acknowledges, a 4.51 percent discount to the closing price of Schlumberger stock on April 3, 2007 ($70.95), the day prior to the date of the offer, and a 5.69 percent discount to yesterday's closing price of $71.84.    Schlumberger would like to inform its shareholders that it does not recommend or endorse this offer and that the company is in no way associated with TRC Capital Corporation.    Schlumberger cautions its shareholders that mini-tender offers such as this one avoid many of the investor protections afforded for larger tender offers, including the filing of disclosure and other tender offer documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and other procedures required by United States securities laws. Schlumberger is in no way associated with TRC Capital Corporation, its mini-tender offer or the offer documentation.    Schlumberger strongly urges shareholders to obtain current market quotations for their shares of Schlumberger common stock, to consult with their financial advisors and to exercise caution with respect to TRC Capital's offer. Shareholders who may already have tendered their shares may withdraw them by providing the written notice described in the TRC Capital offering documents prior to the expiration of the offer currently scheduled for 12:01 a.m., New York time, on Friday, May 4, 2007.    The SEC has issued an investor alert regarding these mini-tender offers. The SEC has noted that, in making the offers at below-market prices, bidders are "hoping that they will catch investors off guard if the investors do not compare the offer price to the current market price." The SEC advisory may be found at www.sec.gov/investor/pubs/minitend.htm. The Canadian Securities Administrators have also issued an advisory entitled "Mini-Tender Offers: Watch Out For Mini-Tender Offers Below Market Price!", which may be found at www.osc.gov.on.ca/Media/NewsReleases/1999/nr_19990927_mini.jsp.    Schlumberger refers broker/dealers and other market participants in the dissemination of TRC Capital's offer to the SEC's recommendations to broker/dealers in these circumstances, which can be found at www.sec.gov/divisions/marketreg/minitenders/sia072401.htm and to Information Memo Number 01-27 issued by the New York Stock Exchange on Sept. 28, 2001, regarding the dissemination of mini-tender offer materials, which can be found under the "Market Professional - Information Memos" tab on the NYSE website at www.nyse.com.    About Schlumberger    Schlumberger is the world's leading oilfield services company supplying technology, information solutions and integrated project management that optimize reservoir performance for customers working in the oil and gas industry. The company employs more than 70,000 people of over 140 nationalities working in approximately 80 countries. Schlumberger supplies a wide range of products and services from seismic acquisition and processing; formation evaluation; well testing and directional drilling to well cementing and stimulation; artificial lift and well completions; and consulting, software and information management. In 2006, Schlumberger operating revenue was $19.23 billion. For more information, visit www.SLB.com.         /CONTACT: Schlumberger Limited, Houston Jean-Francois Poupeau, +1 713-375-3535 Vice President of Communications and Investor Relations or Debashis Gupta, +1 713-375-3535 Investor Relations Manager investor-relations@slb.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 12:28 ET (16:28 GMT)

Headline: Volkswagen: 1Q Vehicle Sales In China, HK Up 23% To 202,623
Story: SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--Volkswagen AG's (VLKAY) said Friday its vehicle sales in mainland China and Hong Kong rose 23% in the first quarter of 2007 from the year-earlier period to 202,623 units.   Volkswagen Group China said in a statement the vehicle sales, including those from its two joint ventures, Shanghai Volkswagen and FAW-Volkswagen, exceeded 200,000 units for the first time in a single quarter.     -By Siobhain Ryan, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; siobhain.ryan@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 00:26 ET (04:26 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Wal-Mart Names Simon Oper Chief Of US Stores >WMT
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) named Bill Simon chief operating officer of its U.S. stores, effective immediately.   The Bentonville, Ark., retailing giant also named Pat Curran executive vice president of people for U.S. operations.   Both will continue reporting directly to Eduardo Castro-Wright, president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores U.S.   These moves are the latest in a series of executive shifts at Wal-Mart. Last week, the company said it was removing a layer of management between Chief Executive Officer Lee Scott and its U.S. stores, shifting vice president of U.S. stores John Menzer to an administrative role with added responsibilities. That put Castro-Wright, CEO of Wal-Mart's 3,443-store U.S. division since September 2005, directly under Scott.   Castro-Wright, 52 years old, made dramatic changes in the division in 18 months, overhauling its field structure, remodeling hundreds of stores to various degrees, paring its inventory and revamping store schedules to have more workers on hand at busy shopping times.   Wal-Mart said Simon will be responsible for all five operating presidents. He will also oversee asset protection and the professional services group, which includes the pharmacy and optical business and in-store medical clinics.   Simon previously worked for Brinker International Inc. (EAT) as senior vice president of global business development.   Curran was most recently senior vice president of Wal-Mart store operations for the mid-Atlantic and Southeast areas.   -Josee Rose; 201-938-5400; josee.rose@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 12:28 ET (16:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Sonic Solutions Receives Additional Notice of Non-Compliance from Nasdaq
Story: NOVATO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--April 06, 2007--   Sonic Solutions(R) (NASDAQ:SNIC) today announced that, as expected, on April 2, 2007, it received an additional notice of non-compliance from the Listing Qualifications Staff of The Nasdaq Stock Market (the "Staff") due to the Company's failure to solicit proxies and hold an annual meeting for its fiscal year ended March 31, 2006 on or before March 31, 2007 (the "Additional Staff Determination"), as required by Nasdaq Marketplace Rules 4350(e) and 4350(g), respectively.     As previously announced by the Company, the Company received a notice of non-compliance from the Staff based upon the Company's failure to timely file its Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended December 31, 2006, as required by Nasdaq Marketplace Rule 4310(c)(14) (the "Nasdaq filing requirement"). On March 22, 2007, the Company appeared at a hearing before a Nasdaq Listing Qualifications Panel (the "Panel") to present its plan for regaining compliance with the Nasdaq filing requirement. The Panel has not yet rendered its decision in connection with that hearing.     Nasdaq has offered the Company an opportunity to make a submission in response to the Additional Staff Determination and the Company intends to make such a submission to the Panel by the Nasdaq deadline of April 9, 2007. The Company's securities will remain listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market pending the issuance of a decision by the Panel with respect to both the filing and annual meeting deficiencies. However, there can be no assurance that the Panel will grant the Company's request for continued listing.     As previously announced on February 1, 2007, Sonic has commenced a voluntary review of its historical and current stock option grant practices and related accounting. Based on the review, the audit committee and Sonic management have preliminarily concluded that, under applicable accounting guidance, Sonic lacks sufficient documentation for certain historical option grants and that the measurement dates associated with these option grants will need to be adjusted. Further, as previously announced, the audit committee, after consultation with management and the Company's board of directors, has determined that the Company's annual and interim financial statements may no longer be relied upon.     Sonic believes it will have to record additional non-cash charges for stock-based compensation expense and restate previous financial statements, and that such charges will be material. Sonic is not yet able to determine the amount of such charges or the resulting tax and accounting impact of these actions. Sonic intends to file its restated financial results and related periodic reports as quickly as possible.       About Sonic Solutions     Sonic Solutions (Nasdaq: SNIC - News; http://www.sonic.com) is the leader in digital media software, providing a broad range of interoperable, platform-independent software tools and applications for creative professionals, business and home users, and technology partners. Sonic's products range from advanced DVD authoring systems and interactive content delivery technologies used to produce the majority of Hollywood DVD film releases, to the award-winning Roxio(R)-branded CD and DVD creation, playback and backup solutions that have become the premier choice for consumers, prosumers and business users worldwide.     Sonic products are globally available from major retailers as well as online at Sonic.com and Roxio.com, and are bundled with PCs, after-market drives and consumer electronic devices. Sonic's digital media creation engine is the de facto standard and has been licensed by major software and hardware manufacturers, including Adobe, Microsoft, Scientific-Atlanta, Sony, and many others. Sonic is headquartered in Marin County, California.     Sonic, the Sonic logo, Sonic Solutions, and Roxio are trademarks or registered trademarks of Sonic Solutions in the U.S. and/or other countries. All other company or product names are trademarks or registered trademarks of their respective owners and, in some cases, are used by Sonic under license.     Safe Harbor Statement under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995:     All statements included or incorporated by reference in this release, other than statements or characterizations of historical fact, are forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations, estimates and projections about our business and industry, management's beliefs, and certain assumptions made by us, all of which are subject to change. Forward-looking statements can often be identified by words such as "anticipates," "expects," "intends," "plans," "predicts," "believes," "seeks," "estimates," "may," "will," "should," "would," "could," "potential," "continue," "ongoing," similar expressions, and variations or negatives of these words. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future results and are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially and adversely from those expressed in any forward-looking statement.     These risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to, our ability to persuade the Nasdaq Listing Qualifications Panel to grant our request for continued listing on The Nasdaq Stock Market; the scope of the equity awards for which accounting measurement dates will change; the amount and timing of stock-based compensation and other additional expenses to be recorded, and the corresponding restatement of our financial statements; other accounting adjustments that may result from review of our financial statements for the periods in question; other ramifications of our inability to file required reports with the SEC on a timely basis; potential claims and proceedings relating to such matters, including shareholder litigation and action by the SEC or other governmental agencies; other actions taken or required as a result of the review; and negative tax or other implications for the company resulting from the accounting adjustments and other factors.     Our Annual Report on Form 10-K, subsequent Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, recent Current Reports on Form 8-K, and other SEC filings discuss important risk factors that could contribute to such differences or otherwise affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. The forward-looking statements in this release speak only as of the date they are made. Except as required by law, we undertake no obligation to revise or update publicly any forward-looking statement for any reason.        CONTACT: Sonic Solutions               A. Clay Leighton, 415-893-8000 (Chief Financial Officer)               Fax: 415-893-8008               clay_leighton@sonic.com               or               StreetSmart Investor Relations               Brooke Deterline, 415-893-7824               Anne Leschin, 415-775-1788               investinsonic@sonic.com        SOURCE: Sonic Solutions  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 06, 2007 16:30 ET (20:30 GMT)
